awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  A Low-Cost Structured Light Monitoring System for Additive Manufacturing Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a structured light optical monitoring system for metal additive manufacturing (MAM). Metal additive manufacturing (MAM) is a rapidly expanding industry, impacting aerospace, energy, and medical industries, among others. However, the lack of in-process monitoring for part quality is recognized as a hindrance to rapid, wide-scale industry adoption. The monitoring system under development is designed to be implemented within the MAM process to measure the quality of parts and detect defects in an in-process fashion.  The proposed technology may allow for part qualification and increased part output while reducing the cost of the fabrication process and increasing US manufacturing competitiveness.  In addition, the proposed technology may reduce material waste when compared to traditional subtractive techniques.  The goal of this technology is to reduce the per-part cost of MAM by allowing immediate cancellation of builds that include defective parts.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a structured light monitoring system (SLMS) for metal additive manufacturing (MAM). SLMS uses a projector and a camera to quickly measure the three-dimensional height of multiple features of a part during its fabrication in MAM settings. Dimensional results from the SLMS are compared against values predefined by technicians to determine if the part is within defect tolerance. A patented measurement model is included to gauge the uncertainty of each measurement point to further bolster the statistical part health monitoring method. Initial results show that the SLMS is capable of resolving porosity defects as small as 25 microns, and powder deposition defects as small as 80 microns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this award was to support the 3-person team (entrepreneurial lead EL, technical lead, and i-corps mentor) to conduct market research over the course of 6 weeks to determine viability of commercialization of an invention from UCSD research. The invention under market scrutiny was a monitoring system for additive manufacturing (industrial 3D printing) which detects defects during the manufacturing process.

Entrepreneurial programming was consumed by the team every week of the award to address each section of the business model canvas (customer segments, channels, costs, partners, etc), and each week a presentation was given by the entrepreneurial lead (Niall O’Dowd) to the i-corps cohort. Additionally, the team was tasked with conducting 100 customer interviews with stakeholders in the commercial industry, such as potential customers, influencers, subject matter experts, distributors, competitors, marketers, etc. The customer interview goal was accomplished, and each interview was logged in the GLDR platform. The grant provided a small fund to support minimum product development, stipends for the EL and TL, and conference travel/customer travel budgets.

No scientific or engineering related work was to be accomplished in this project, thus the outcomes are simply knowledge gained through entrepreneurial programming, customer interviews, and conference travel. Some key merit outcomes and broad impacts included:

Product Market Fit

o   Customer interviews and entrepreneurial programming helped the team find clear indication of product market fit

o   Development of a business model canvas with data supported by specific customer interviews, including customer segment, partners, channels, etc.

Market Entry

o   Integration and visibility into the commercial additive manufacturing market

o   Establishment of the EL as a known member of the additive manufacturing community

o   Practiced cold calling, requesting warm introductions to customers, methods of communicating with customers and investors

Measurable outcomes

o   The EL continued to raise $600,000 (Advanced Manufacturing Office DoE) and founded a startup based on the technology focused from the program (Additive Monitoring Systems, AMS)

o   AMS has created 2 jobs in the US after 6 months of operation

o   The EL continued to participate in an additional regional i-corps program (Polsky Center Node Program, Award #1735858)

o   The EL is supporting 3 interns in the summer 2022 (1 Science Undergraduate Laboratory Internship, 2 Students for Energy & Entrepreneurial Development interns) to support technical and business development

In addition to these outcomes, an extremely valuable outcome of the NSF i-corps program are the relationships developed through customer interviews. Using the contacts which the EL established, AMS has built relationships at research and industrial partners such as NASA, Air Force Research Lab, University of Louisville, Sigma Labs, Applied Research Laboratory at Penn State, Argonne National Laboratory, and Oak Ridge National Laboratory. These relationships (aside from NASA and AFRL) are supported by activity, as each of these agencies are currently contractual subcontractors spread across $2,190,000 of pending (3/2022) grants and contracts submitted by AMS. 

 


Last Modified: 03/30/2022
Modified by: Michael D Todd
